title: `std::io::Error::description()` is deprecated, but its recommended replacement gives a different result

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-io
labels.description: Area: std::io, std::fs, std::net and std::path

body:
I would like my shell utilities written in Rust to print the same style of error messages as their traditional C brethren which use e.g. `perror` to give error messages of the form "foo: can't read "bar": permission denied".

There is therefore a need to turn an `io::Error` into the text "permission denied" and the like. `io::Error::description()` does this, but it is marked as deprecated and causes a compiler warning to "use the Display impl or to_string()". However, the `Display` impl on `io::Error` formats the `Repr::Os` (i.e. errno-like) variant using `write!(fmt, "{} (os error {})", detail, code)` which produces the text "Operation not permitted (os error 1)". The integer value of errno is an implementation detail which just adds visual clutter.

(Right now, I just add `#allow(deprecated)` to the call to `description()`, but this is a code smell that I'd like to get rid of.)

To fix this, simply remove the error number from the `Display` impl since ["`Display` is for user-facing output"](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/core/fmt/trait.Display.html) and this kind of noise does not belong there. It is still in the `Debug` output for anybody who wants it. Alternatively, if the `Display` format is frozen (why?) then another method which gets at just the error text would be helpful. `ErrorKind::as_str()` could be made public, for example.
